title: The Pentagon vs. Anthropic + An A.I. Agent Slandered Me + Hot Mess Express
summary: This would be an unprecedented escalation against a U.S. company.

title: His Team Devised Ways to Keep World Cup Crowds Safe
summary: Michael Silevitch leads a research center dedicated to protecting busy public spaces. Last April, he was instructed to “end all work” immediately.

title: A.I. Isn’t Coming for Every White-Collar Job. At Least Not Yet.
summary: Tech workers are increasingly worried that the artificial intelligence they are building will replace them. But some are optimistic that it is just one more tool to work with.

title: West Virginia Sues Apple, Claiming It Allows Sharing of Child Sexual Abuse Material
summary: The state’s attorney general said in a lawsuit filed on Thursday that the company declined to use tools that recognize the material stored on iCloud.

title: Mark Zuckerberg Takes the Stand in Social Media Addiction Trial
summary: Meta’s chief executive said users spent a lot of time on Instagram because of its value, as he was grilled about child safety issues in front of a jury.

title: Defense Department and Anthropic Square Off in Dispute Over A.I. Safety
summary: How artificial intelligence will be used in future battlefields is an issue that has turned increasingly political and may put Anthropic in a bind.

title: Decoding the A.I. Beliefs of Anthropic and Its C.E.O., Dario Amodei
summary: The company is at odds with the Pentagon over how its A.I. will be used. The conflict has its roots in the foundational plan for Anthropic.

title: Meta Begins $65 Million Election Push to Advance A.I. Agenda
summary: Meta’s biggest election investment aims to prevent state legislation that it fears could inhibit artificial intelligence development. Its spending starts this week in Texas and Illinois.

title: What Do A.I. Chatbots Discuss Among Themselves? We Sent One to Find Out.
summary: We interviewed our bot about what it learned on Moltbook, the A.I.-only social network.

title: How to Watch Free Live Television on Your Phone or Tablet
summary: Whether by app or old-school antennas, budget-friendly options abound.

title: Uber Taking Steps to Expand Number of EV Chargers Near Its Drivers
summary: The company said it would encourage companies that operated chargers to install them in neighborhoods where its drivers lived and work.

title: Chatbots Are the New Influencers Brands Must Woo
summary: Companies are realizing they can no longer simply promote themselves to potential customers. They have to win over the robots, too.

title: With Niche Tech World References, Vibe Hopes Its Billboards Reach Start-Up Insiders
summary: Billboards that wouldn’t make sense to people outside the tech industry have become common in the Bay Area. One company took the microtargeting game to another level.

title: User Issues With X Appear to Have Resolved
summary: The social media site was the subject of user complaints early Monday.

title: Their Secret to a Happy Marriage? A Translation App
summary: He speaks English. She speaks Mandarin. The secret to their happy marriage: Microsoft Translator.

title: Could an Electronic Coach Help Ski Jumpers Leap Farther?
summary: Future Olympic prospects are testing a device that can give them corrective advice in real time as they hurtle into the air.

title: More Than Ever, Videos Expose the Truth. And Cloud It, Too.
summary: In Minneapolis, videos of the Alex Pretti killing undermined the federal government’s account. But an A.I. video of Brad Pitt shows the dangers ahead.

title: Ring Ends Deal to Link Neighborhood Cameras After Backlash to Super Bowl Ad
summary: A commercial about a lost dog being reunited with his family ignited concerns that a “Search Party” feature posed privacy risks. Ring parted ways with the tech company Flock Safety.

title: David J. Farber, ‘Grandfather of the Internet,’ Dies at 91
summary: A researcher, professor and federal policy adviser, he guided students who went on to do groundbreaking work in connecting the world online.

title: Homeland Security Demands Social Media Sites Reveal Names Behind Anti-ICE Posts
summary: The department has sent Google, Meta and other companies hundreds of subpoenas for information on accounts that track or comment on Immigration and Customs Enforcement, officials and tech workers said.
